tn.text: This continues the story of Paul, Silas, and Timothy's missionary trip. They arrive in Thessalonica,  apparently without Luke, since he says "they" and not "we."
Here the word "they" refers to Paul and Silas. Compare [[:en:bible:notes:act:16:40|16:40]]. The word "them" refers to the Jews at the synagogue in Thessalonica.
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Luke, the author, starts to tell a new part of the story.
"traveled through"
These are coastal cities in Macedonia. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
Here "came" can be translated as "went" or "arrived." AT: "they came to the city" or "they arrived at the city" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_go]])
"as his habit was" or "as his common practice was." Paul usually went to the synagogue on the Sabbath when Jews would be present.
"on each Sabbath day for three weeks"

tn.ref: reasoned with them from the scriptures
tn.text: Paul explained what the scriptures means in order to prove to the Jews that Jesus is the Messiah. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
"gave them reasons" or "debated with them" or "discussed with them"
Here the word "He" refers to Paul. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:17:01|17:02]])

Possible meanings are 1) to explain the scriptures in a way that people can understand is spoken of as if Paul were opening something so people can see what is inside of it) or 2) Paul was literally opening a book or scroll and reading from it. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]]
"it was part of God's plan"
"to come back to life"
"from among the dead ones." The phrase "the dead ones" refers to the spirits of people who have died. To come back from among them means to become alive again.
This can be stated in active form. AT: "the Jews believed" or "the Jews understood"
"and became associated with Paul"
This means those who worship God but have not converted to Judaism through circumcision
"a large crowd"
Here the word "they" refers to the unbelieving Jews and wicked men from the marketplace.
The feeling of jealousy is spoken of as if jealousy were actually moving the person. AT: "feeling very jealous" or "feeling very angry" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
It can be stated explicitly that these Jews were jealous because some of the Jews and Greeks believed Paul's message. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_explicit]])
Here "took" does not mean the Jews took these people by force. It means the Jews persuaded these wicked men to help them.
"some evil men." The word "men" here refers specifically to males.
"from the public square." This is a public place of business, where buying and selling of goods, cattle, or services take place.

tn.ref: set the city in an uproar
tn.text: Here "the city" stands for the people in the city. AT: "caused the people of the city to be in an uproar" or "caused the people of the city to riot" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"Violently attacking the house." This probably means the people were throwing rocks at the house and trying to break down the door of the house.
This is the name of a man. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
Possible meanings or "people" are 1) a governmental or legal group of citizens gathered to make a decision or 2) a mob.
Here "brothers" refers to believers. AT: "some other believers"
"in the presence of the officials"
The Jewish leaders were speaking and the phrase, "These men," refers to Paul and Silas.

This phrase is another way of saying Paul and Silas where causing trouble everywhere they went. The Jewish leaders were exaggerating the influence Paul and Silas were having with their teaching. AT: "caused trouble everywhere in the world" (UDB) or "caused trouble everywhere they have gone" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_hyperbole|Hyperbole]] and [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_idiom]])
This phrase signals that Jason was in agreement with the apostles' troubling message.
The word "they" refers to the officials of the city."
The word "them" refers to Jason and the other believers they had brought the city officials.
"worried" or "anxious"

tn.ref: had taken financial security from Jason and the rest
tn.text: This money was a promise of good behavior; money which might be returned if all went well or might be used to repair the damages brought on by bad behavior. AT: "had received a bond" or "had received money"
The words "the rest" refers to other believers that the Jews brought before the officials.
Paul and Silas travel on to the town of Berea.
The word "brothers" here refers to men and women believers. AT: "the believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

The word "now" is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Luke tells background information about the people in Berea and how they were willing to listen to Paul and examine what he said. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
These "well-born" people were willing to think more objectively about new ideas than other people. AT: "more open minded" or "more willing to listen"
Here "word" refers to a teaching. AT: "listened to the teaching" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
These Bereans were prepared to examine earnestly Paul's teachings about the scripture.
"carefully reading and evaluating the scriptures every day"
"the things Paul said were true"
Athens is down the coast from Barea which is in Macedonia. Athens was one of the most important cities in Greece. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
"found out" or "heard" (UDB)

This speaks about their agitating people as though it were a person stirring a liquid and causing the things at the bottom of the liquid to rise to the surface. AT: "went there and agitated" or "went there and disturbed" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"and worried the crowds" or "caused dread and fear among the people"
The word "brothers" here refers to men and women believers. AT: "believers" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])
"to go to the coast." From here Paul would probably sail to another city.
"who were accompanying Paul" or "who were going along with Paul"

tn.ref: they received from him instructions for Silas and Timothy
tn.text: "he told them to instruct Silas and Timothy." This can also be stated as a direct quotation as in the UDB. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_quotations]])
This is another part of the story of Paul and Silas' travels. Paul is now in Athens where he is waiting for Silas and Timothy to join him.
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Luke starts to tell a new part of the story.

tn.ref: his spirit was provoked within him as he saw the city full of idols
tn.text: Here "spirit" stands for Paul himself. This can be stated in active form. AT: "he became upset because he saw that there were idols everywhere in the city" or "seeing the idols everywhere in the city upset him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
"he debated" or "he discussed." This means that there is interaction from the listeners rather than only his preaching. They are talking with him as well.
This refers to Gentiles who give praise to God and follow him but do not obey all of the Jewish laws.
"in the public square." This is a public place of business, where buying and selling of goods, cattle, or services take place.
Here the words "him," "He, "and "he" refer to Paul.

These people believed all things were formed by chance and that the gods were too busy being happy to be bothered with governing the universe. They rejected the resurrection and wanted only simple pleasures. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
These people believed freedom comes from resigning oneself to fate. They rejected a personal loving God and the resurrection. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
"happened upon him"
"And some of the philosophers said"

The word "babbler" was used to refer to birds picking up seeds as food. It refers negatively to a person who only knows a little bit of information. The philosophers said Paul had bits of information which were not worth listening to. AT: "What is this uneducated person" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
"Other philosophers said"

tn.ref: He seems to be a preacher
tn.text: "He seems to be a proclaimer" or "He seems to be on a mission of spreading the message"
This is not in the sense of "odd," but in the sense of "foreign," that is, gods that Greeks and Romans do not worship or know about.
Here the words "They" and "we" refer to the Epicurean and Stoic philosophers.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]] and [[:en:bible:notes:act:17:18|17:18]])
The words "him," "He" and "you" refer to Paul. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:17:18|17:18]])
This does not mean they arrested Paul. The philosophers invited Paul to speak formally to their leaders.
The "Areopagus" was the place where  the leaders met. AT: "to the leaders that met on the Areopagus" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
Here the leaders on the Areopagus are speaking. This can stated as a new sentence. AT: "the Areopagus. The leaders said to Paul"
This is a prominent rock outcropping or hill in Athens upon which the supreme court of Athens may have met. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])

tn.ref: For you bring some strange things to our ears
tn.text: Paul's teachings about Jesus and the resurrection are spoken of as an object that a person can bring to another person. Here "ears" refers to what they hear. AT: "For you teachings some things that we have never heard before" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Luke tells background information about the people who lived in Athens and their interest in new teachings. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_background]])
"Athenians" are people from Athens, a city near the coast below Macedonia (present day Greece). (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
"and the foreigners"

tn.ref: spent their time in nothing but either
tn.text: Here "time" is spoken of as if it were an object that a person could spend. AT: "loved only either" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: telling or listening about something new
tn.text: "discussing new philosophical ideas" or "talking about what was new to them" (UDB)
Paul begins his speech to the philosophers on the Areopagus.
Paul is referring to the Athenians' public display of honoring the gods through prayers, building altars, and offering sacrifices.
"Because as I walked past" or "I walked along"
Possible meanings are 1) "to a certain unknown god" or 2) "to a god not known." This was a specific writing or inscription on that altar.
In the most general sense, the "world" refers to the heavens and the earth and everything in them.
"because he is the Lord." Here "he" is referring to the unknown god mentioned in [[:en:bible:notes:act:17:22|17:23]] that Paul is explaining is the Lord God.
The words "heaven" and "earth" are used together to mean all beings and things in heaven and earth. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_merism]])
Here "hands" stands for people. AT: "built by the hands of people" or "that people built" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Neither is he served by men's hands
tn.text: Here "served" has the sense of a doctor treating a patient to make the patient well again. AT: "Neither do men's hands take care of him" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Here "hands" stands for the whole person. AT: "by humans" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])
"because he himself." The word "himself" is added for emphasis. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_rpronouns]])
Here the words "he" and "him" refer to the one true God, the creator.
The words "their" and "them" refer to every nation of people living on the surface of the earth.
In using the word "us," Paul includes himself, his audience, and every nation. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive|Inclusive "We"]])
This means Adam, the first person God created. This can be stated to include Eve. It was through Adam and Eve that God made all other people. AT: "one couple" (UDB)

tn.ref: having determined their appointed seasons and the boundaries of their living areas
tn.text: This can be stated as a new sentence. AT: "And he determined when and where they would live"
This word marks a statement that is said because of what Paul said previously.

tn.ref: they should seek God and perhaps they might reach out to him and find him
tn.text: Desiring to learn about God and to have a relationship with him is spoken of as if it were a person literally looking around to find someone and reaching out to him. AT: "they should learn about him so that they may understand that they need him and become one of his people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: he is not far from any one of us
tn.text: This can be stated in positive form. AT: "he is very near to everyone of us" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_litotes|Litotes]])
Here the words "him" and "his" refer to God. (See: [[:en:bible:notes:act:17:24|17:24]])
When Paul says "we" here, he includes himself as well as his hearers. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_inclusive|Inclusive "We"]])
"Because of him"
Because God created everyone, all people are spoken of as if they were God's literal children. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])
Here "divinity" refers to God's nature or attributes. AT: "that God" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: sculptured with the art and thought of man
tn.text: This can be stated in active form. - "which a man then uses his skill to make it into something that he has designed" or "made with art and man's thoughts" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_activepassive]])
Paul finishes his speech to the philosophers in the Areopagus, which he began in [[:en:bible:notes:act:17:22|17:22]].
Here the word "he" refers to God.
This word marks a statement that is said because of what was said previously.

tn.ref: God overlooked the times of ignorance
tn.text: "God decided not to punish people during the time of ignorance"
This refers to the time before God fully revealed himself through Jesus Christ and before people truly knew how to obey God.
This means all people whether male or female. AT: "all people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_gendernotations]])

tn.ref: when he will judge the world in righteousness by the man he has chosen
tn.text: "when the man he has chosen will judge the world in righteousness"
Here "world" refers to the people. AT: "he will judge all people" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
"justly" or "fairly"

tn.ref: God has given proof of this man
tn.text: "God has demonstrated his choice of this man"
"from among the dead ones." The phrase "the dead ones" refers to the spirits of people who have died. To come back from among them means to become alive again.
This is the end of the part of the story about Paul in Athens. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_endofstory]])

Here the word "We" refers to the men of Athens. They were talking directly to Paul but not including Paul in their group. Possibly they were just being polite though some really did want to hear Paul again.(See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclusive|Exclusive "We"]])
This word is used here to mark a break in the main storyline. Here Luke shifts from Paul's teachings to the reaction of the people of Athens.
These are the people who were present at the Areopagus listening to Paul.
"some ridiculed Paul" or "some laughed at Paul." These did not believe it was possible for someone to die and then return to life.
Dionysius is a man's name. Areopagite implies that Dionysius was one of the judges at the council of Areopagus. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names|How to Translate Names]])
This is the name of a woman. (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:translate_names]])
